Job.JobTitle: Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School at Lewiston High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Lewiston High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School at Lewiston High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

SUMMARY: To help each participating student achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.
STIPEND
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES. Other duties may be assigned.
Coaches individual participants in the skills necessary for excellent achievement in the sport involved. Plans and schedules a regular program of practice in season. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility or area in which assigned sport is conducted at all times that students are present. Maintains accurate statistics, records, and results of the season. Enforces discipline and sportsmanlike behavior at all times, and establishes and oversees penalties for breach of such standards by individual students. Maintains competency in rules, rule interpretations, meet procedures, coaching techniques, and general information about all aspects of the sport. Establishes performance criteria for eligibility in interscholastic competition in this sport. and is consistent in establishing criteria for eligibility in competition. Adheres to a highly efficient and technically sound program of injury prevention and follow up. Works closely with the athletics director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. Recommends purchase of equipment, supplies, and uniforms. Maintains necessary attendance forms, insurance records, and similar paperwork. Accounts for all equipment or delegates the responsibility. Develops a consistent and positive public communications procedure through the school and media to inform the parents and the general public about the athletic program.
SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES: Supervises students of particular program.
QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE: Experience in physical education, coaching, first-aid, CPR, and sports medicine preferred.
LANGUAGE SKILLS: Ability to read and interpret documents such as safety rules, operating and maintenance instructions, and procedure manuals. Ability to write routine reports and correspondence. Ability to speak effectively before groups of students or employees of the district.
MATHEMATICAL SKILLS: Ability to calculate figures and amounts such as discounts, interest, commissions, proportions, percentages, area, circumference, and volume. Ability to apply concepts of basic algebra and geometry.
REASONING ABILITY: Ability to apply common sense understanding to carry out instructions furnished in written, oral, or diagram form. Ability to deal with problems involving several concrete variable standardized situations.
OTHER SKILLS AND ABILITIES:

The Coach, Track & Field, JFDS role at Bangor School Department emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach, Track & Field, JFDS coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Bangor School Department, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach, Track & Field, JFDS reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Bangor School Department at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach, Track & Field, JFDS may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach, Track & Field, JFDS monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach, Track & Field, JFDS must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Bangor School Department.

The Football Coach, 7th Grade at Eric Curtis is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Football Coach, 7th Grade are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Eric Curtis use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Football Coach, 7th Grade recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Football Coach, 7th Grade collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Football Coach, 7th Grade maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Eric Curtis. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Football Coach, 8th Grade role at Bonny Eagle Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Football Coach, 8th Grade is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Bonny Eagle Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Football Coach, 8th Grade sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Bonny Eagle Middle School, the Football Coach, 8th Grade is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Football Coach, 8th Grade at Bonny Eagle Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach position at Kevin Ryan provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Kevin Ryan, the Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach at Kevin Ryan is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Cheerleading Coach - Massabesic Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
Position Summary Massabesic Middle School is seeking an enthusiastic, student-centered Assistant Cheerleading Coach to collaborate with the Head Coach in developing a safe, inclusive, and competitive cheer program. The Assistant Coach will support skill development, game-day performances, and foster a positive team culture aligned with district and MPA expectations. Key Responsibilities
Assist in planning and leading practices focused on cheer fundamentals, safety, and progressive skill development. Support the Head Coach with choreography, stunting instruction, sideline cheers, and halftime routines. Promote a positive learning environment emphasizing teamwork, sportsmanship, accountability, and school pride. Ensure consistent supervision and safety of all student-athletes during practices, games, transportation, and team events. Reinforce academic, behavioral, and eligibility standards in collaboration with school administration. Communicate effectively with student-athletes, families, and staff as directed by the Head Coach. Assist with organization and distribution/collection of team equipment and uniforms. Comply with all district policies, MPA regulations, and NFHS coaching safety standards.
Qualifications Required:
Prior experience in cheerleading, dance, gymnastics, coaching, or supervising youth athletics. Ability to teach and demonstrate proper stunt and tumbling safety techniques. Commitment to positive youth development and equity in school-based athletics. Successful completion of district-required onboarding processes (fingerprinting, background check). Maine Department of Education Coaching Certification or willingness to obtain. First Aid/CPR certification. Experience working within school athletics or competitive cheer programs.
Compensation
Stipend per negotiated agreement with RSU 57. Details provided during the hiring process.

Job.JobTitle: HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach at Gorham School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Gorham School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Pom Pon Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Grand Blanc East Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Pom Pon Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Grand Blanc East Middle School, the Pom Pon Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Pom Pon Coach at Grand Blanc East Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce at Pierce Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Pierce Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Pierce Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Pierce Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce role at Pierce Middle School.

The Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach position at Raytown South High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. From an instructional perspective, the Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach at Raytown South High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Job.JobDescription:
The Head Volleyball Coach - Big Sky High School at Big Sky High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head Volleyball Coach - Big Sky High School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Big Sky High School, the Head Volleyball Coach - Big Sky High School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head Volleyball Coach - Big Sky High School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Big Sky High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head Volleyball Coach - Big Sky High School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Wrestling Coach role at Phillips Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Wrestling Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Phillips Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Wrestling Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Wrestling Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Wrestling Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Phillips Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Wrestling Coach at Phillips Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Phillips Middle School. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) position at Carrboro High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Carrboro High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) role at Carrboro High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Cheerleading Coach at Chapel Hill High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the JV Cheerleading Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Chapel Hill High School, the JV Cheerleading Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The JV Cheerleading Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Chapel Hill High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The JV Cheerleading Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

POSITION TITLE: Interscholastic Athletics Coach LOCATION: Middle Schools and High Schools PAY GRADE: District Coaching Supplement Scale FLSA STATUS: Non-Exempt REPORTS TO: Athletic Director/Principal WORK WEEK SCHEDULE: Monday - Friday WORK HOURS: 3:00 PM- 8:00 PM; varies depending on season, includes nights and weekends MONTHS/YR: Varies - Part-Time
POSITION PURPOSE To instruct student athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the student shall receive instruction that will lead to the formulation of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline and self-confidence.
MINIMUM QUALIFICATION STANDARDS KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES Ability to organize and supervise a total sports program Previous successful coaching experience Substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and at the same time must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the sport Must know and follow the rules of the North Carolina High School Athletic Association, the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction, and the Pender County Board of Education
EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND EXPERIENCE Successful completion of the NFHS “Fundamentals of Coaching” certification course Annual completion of the NFHS “Concussions in Sports” course or an equivalent concussion curriculum prior to the first date of practice in their sport If coaching cheerleading, must complete the NFHS “American Association of Cheerleading Coaches Spirit Safety Certification” course prior to the first date of practice Current CPR/AED certification; recommended to successfully complete the NFHS “First Aid for Coaches” course Must complete the NFHS “Sudden Cardiac Arrest” Course after June 1 and prior to the first practice All high school head coaches must attend one of the NCHSAA state rules clinics in their assigned sport.
CERTIFICATION AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS Must hold and maintain a valid motor vehicle operator’s license according to the State of NC requirements
SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS Ability to work flexible hours (evenings, weekends)
PREFERRED QUALIFICATIONS Hold valid driver license for driving an activity bus in Pender County Schools Be a bona fide member of the school faculty Be an Accredited Interscholastic Coach or Certified Interscholastic Coach by the NFHS Playing experience at the high school and college level
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport Assesses a player’s skill and assigns team positions Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both team and individual development Works with the athletic director to schedule facilities for practices and competitions Assigns duties to an assistant coach as necessary Coaches and Instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport Observes players, during competition and practice to determine the needs for individual or team improvement Determines game strategy based on the team’s capabilities Establishes and maintains standards of student behavior and provides proper supervision of athletes at all times Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility standards are met; and encourages student athletes to maintain high academic standards Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student Follows state, conference, and district regulations governing the athletic program Models and maintains appropriate conduct and behavior towards players, officials, and spectators Acts a team representative and promotes the sport by communicating with booster clubs, service organizations, and the school community Maintains and cares for equipment, supplies, and uniforms, including correct inventory of same Assist with the maintenance of athletic playing areas (i.e. mowing grass, picking up debris, operating a weed eater) Attends staff development, clinics, and other professional activities to improve performance Performs other duties as assigned by the Principal and Athletic Director
WORKING CONDITIONS PHYSICAL DEMANDS Must be able to use a variety of office equipment such as computers and copiers Must be able to frequently lift, carry, push, pull or otherwise move objects up to 20 pounds Due to the amount of time spent working on the computer, standing and walking, physical requirements are consistent with those for light work
WORK ENVIRONMENT Must be able to work in office and public school environments, and come into direct contact with staff and students Travel is required to schools and Central Services offices

Job.JobDescription:
Position Title: Varsity Assistant Coach – Girls Basketball Location: Sheyenne High School Department: Athletics/Activities Reports To: Athletic Director Term: 2025-26 Season Schedule: See Summary for more information. Salary: Position follows the Activities Pay Schedule 2025-2027 Date of last review: August 2025
SUMMARY: The Varsity Assistant – Girls Basketball position is responsible for leading the team in training, instruction, conditioning, and performance. The position provides support and education to athletes in an effort to excel in their given sport in a healthy and safe environment. The position views winning not only as success, but as helping team members reach goals.
Schedule: The schedule and hours for this position vary and aligns to the NDHSAA schedule. For questions regarding the schedule, please contact the building-level athletic director.
To Apply: Please complete the application and include three references.
QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty and requirement satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required for the role. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: (Other duties may be assigned) Collaboration: • Leads training, instruction, conditioning, performance, and selection of athletes. Communication: • Communicates with other coaches, assistant coaches, and athletes in a professional and respectful manner. • Communicates with athletes to provide helpful, positive guidance to ensure athlete growth and safety. • Communicates with officials, opposing coaches, parents, and others in a positive, respectful manner. Providing exemplary behavior for athletes and other learners. Compassion: • Demonstrates and generates, among staff and athletes, an attitude of good sportsmanship and fair play by adhering to the “Coach’s Code of Ethics” and our conference “Sportsmanship Guidelines.” • Understands the complexities of cultural and global issues and how they relate to employee and learners' experiences. • Approaches coaching with a positive, committed mindset. Focusing on athlete well-being. • Develops positive working relationships with school administration, learners, educators, and the wider district community. Creativity: • Connects with team members and shares ideas in an effort to improve the overall learner and employee experience. Critical Thinking: • Develops, organizes, and implements effective practices for athletes to teach proper skills and strategies to compete at an elevated level. Reflection: • Maintains communication with supervisor and director regarding general feedback, career advancement opportunities, and areas of growth opportunities. Resilience: • Maintains composure while dealing with stressful situations. • Proactively seeks out resolutions and takes initiative to resolve knowledge gaps. Responsibility: • Adheres to all West Fargo Public Schools and NDHSAA guidelines and policies. • Provides for the health, safety, and well-being of team members at practices, games, and transportation to and from activities.
PHYSICAL DEMANDS AND WORK ENVIRONMENT: The physical demands and work environment described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. • While performing the essential duties and responsibilities of this role, the employee is regularly required to reach with hands and arms. • While performing the essential duties and responsibilities of this role, the employee is regularly required to stand, walk, bend, talk, and hear. • The specific vision abilities required for this role include close and peripheral vision. • The employee may frequently lift up to ~25 pounds without assistance. • The employee may occasionally lift up to ~50 pounds without assistance. • The employee may have to push/pull up to ~120 pounds while performing the duties of the role. • The employee must work with the public and various WFPS staff while simultaneously managing several competing demands. • The employee may work outdoors and, if so, will be exposed to the applicable weather elements. • The employee may come in contact with bloodborne pathogens or other bodily fluids on rare occasions. • The employee will work in an environment that has a quiet to loud noise level.
Education and/or Experience: • Currently possesses, or has the ability to obtain, an NDHSAA coaching certification. • Experience in the discipline is preferred.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive at Sheyenne High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Sheyenne High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Sheyenne High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Sheyenne High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive role at Sheyenne High School.

Job.JobDescription:
The Coaching at MITCH LUNDE is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Coaching plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at MITCH LUNDE reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Coaching expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Coaching supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Coaching may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at MITCH LUNDE. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The HS-Assistant Boys Wrestling Coach at Williston High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the HS-Assistant Boys Wrestling Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Williston High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The HS-Assistant Boys Wrestling Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the HS-Assistant Boys Wrestling Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The HS-Assistant Boys Wrestling Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Williston High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The High School-Assistant Football Coach role at Robert Conley is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the High School-Assistant Football Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Robert Conley, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The High School-Assistant Football Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Robert Conley, the High School-Assistant Football Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the High School-Assistant Football Coach at Robert Conley is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach, Middle School 2025-2026 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
POSITION TITLE: Assistant Coach, Middle School
QUALIFICATIONS Prior coaching experience required.
RESPONSIBILITIES The assistant coach for any sport has the responsibility for supporting the athletics program in a manner that serves the best interests of the school district and of the student athletes who participate in that program. The assistant coach supports and works cooperatively with the varsity head coach, performing all assigned duties and providing support and assistance as requested. The assistant coach ensures that actions and activities are consistent with and supportive of the athletics program as well as the rules identified by the Nebraska School Activities Association. The assistant coach adheres at all times to the Policies and Regulations and the Practices and Procedures of the Board of Education.
Specific Duties and Responsibilities 1. Ensures the safety and well-being of all student participants. 2. Attends practices and competitive events consistently, demonstrating punctual arrival. 3. Supports and applies approved expectations for learning and classroom performance as a condition for participation in athletics. Monitors and supports students' academic performance to ensure success. 4. Sets and maintains high expectations for the conduct of student athletes, supervising students to assure that all conduct presents the school and the school district in a positive manner. 5. Supports and applies the head coach's plan for teaching and encouraging appropriate student behavior including possible consequences for unacceptable behavior. Assures that the plan is used to support the development of the student athletes and to promote the success of the athletics program. 6. Supports and teaches the athletics program designed by the head coach, enhancing the development of skills and encouraging team play during instruction, practice, and competitive events. 7. Gathers accurate information regarding eligibility of student athletes and provides it to the head coach in a timely manner. Supports the letter and the spirit of eligibility criteria as determined by the school and the district, as well as local and state governing bodies. 8. Participates in district-approved activities with elementary students at the request of the head coach. 9. Communicates effectively with students, staff, and parents. 10. Communicates with the head coach regarding important changes, problems or developments potentially affecting the athletics program or the school. 11. Works cooperatively with all coaches and officials to provide the best possible experience for student-athletes and fans. 12. Supports and contributes to the success of the entire athletics program by encouraging student participation and support for all programs and assisting other programs whenever possible. 13. Communicates with building administrators regarding important changes, problems or developments potentially affecting the athletics program or the school. 14. Supports and contributes to the success of the entire athletics program and the school by encouraging student participation and support for all programs and assisting other programs and coaches whenever possible.
Coaching 1. Plans and schedules all activities related to the athletics program in conjunction with the Head Coach and Athletic Director and in conformance with rules of local and state governing bodies. 2. May design and implement strength and conditioning program that supports the health and safety of student-athletes and promotes the success of the program. 3. Designs practice activities that enhance the development of athletics skills, deepen student-athletes' understanding of the sport, and emphasize the importance of team play to the success of the program. Practices are ordered, with purposeful activities designed to elicit high levels of participation and to emphasize elements of individual and team excellence. 4. Leads student athletes and staff in preparing for and participating in competitive events. Manages all resources effectively to enhance growth, to maximize opportunities for success, and to present the program and the school in a positive manner. 5. Assures that all student participants have arrangements for safe return to the care of respective parent(s) or guardian(s) at the conclusion of activities daily.
Program Administration 1. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility and reports concerns immediately to the appropriate authority. 2. Establishes and maintains an inventory of equipment used in the athletics program and is accountable for the condition and return of all equipment. Monitors program needs and recommends replacement of equipment, supplies, and uniforms in advance of need when possible. 3. Obtains required documentation regarding student eligibility for participation in interscholastic athletics. 4. Assures that reliable data regarding individual and team performances are maintained and reported in a timely manner. 5. Maintains records regarding financial expenditures and reimbursements and submits required reports in a timely manner. 6. Submits an end-of-season report reporting required data and evaluating the success of the program including recommendations for its improvement
* NOTE: The statements herein are intended to describe the general nature and level of work being performed by people assigned to this classification. They are not intended to be construed, as an exhaustive list of all responsibilities, duties, and skills required of personnel so classified. EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER

Job.JobTitle: Activities - Assistant Boys Soccer Coach - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Activities - Assistant Boys Soccer Coach - High School at High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Activities - Assistant Boys Soccer Coach - High School plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Activities - Assistant Boys Soccer Coach - High School expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Activities - Assistant Boys Soccer Coach - High School supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Activities - Assistant Boys Soccer Coach - High School may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Activities - Assistant Girls Soccer Coach - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Activities - Assistant Girls Soccer Coach - High School position at High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Activities - Assistant Girls Soccer Coach - High School is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Activities - Assistant Girls Soccer Coach - High School encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Activities - Assistant Girls Soccer Coach - High School also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Activities - Assistant Girls Soccer Coach - High School role at High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription: Regional School Unit 57 Position: Massabesic Middle School Swim Head Coach Qualifications 1. Ability to organize and supervise a comprehensive athletic program. 2. Previous successful coaching experience in the assigned sport. 3. Substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of swimming, with a commitment to ongoing professional learning and the application of new theories and best practices. 4. Ability to serve as a positive role model for student-athletes through professional conduct, instruction, and leadership. Reports To The Athletic Director, who provides overall objectives and conducts the final evaluation in conjunction with the appropriate school principal(s). Supervises When applicable, advises, coordinates, and supports assistant and middle school coaching staff in collaboration with the Athletic Director and respective principal. Job Goal To instruct student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for individual and team success. The coach will also promote character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment, while continuously upgrading professional knowledge through clinics, observations, and consultation. General Expectations 1. Recognizes that the success of athletic programs strongly influences the community's perception of the school system. Community and parent pressure to win must never override the values of sportsmanship, student well-being, and mental health. 2. Acknowledges that the position may require extended time commitments and involves inherent risks and due process considerations. 3. Exercises sound judgment and common sense in situations not explicitly addressed in this job description. Duties and Responsibilities Program Oversight 1. Demonstrates thorough knowledge of all athletic policies approved by RSU 57 and ensures their consistent implementation. 2. Understands and enforces system, state, and league regulations, interpreting them clearly for staff and athletes. 3. Follows the proper administrative chain of command and attends required meetings. Staff Responsibilities 1. Establishes and communicates the fundamental philosophy, skills, and techniques to be taught within the program. 2. Trains and supports coaching staff and encourages professional growth through approved clinics and development opportunities. 3. Delegates duties, supervises implementation, and evaluates staff effectiveness at the conclusion of the season. 4. Maintains discipline, addresses grievances, and promotes morale and cooperation. 5. Performs other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or principal. Administrative Duties 1. Assists the Athletic Director with scheduling, transportation, and preparation for meets and special events. 2. Coordinates facility use and works with maintenance and school staff to ensure readiness for practices and events. 3. Maintains required documentation for physical examinations, parental consent, and eligibility. 4. Ensures proper care, maintenance, and security of assigned equipment and facilities. 5. Recommends policy, procedural, or program improvements to the Athletic Director. Student Responsibilities 1. Serves as a mentor, promoting character traits such as trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 2. Monitors and supports student-athletes' academic performance and conduct. 3. Provides supervision and safeguards for student-athletes during practices, competitions, and travel. 4. Communicates training rules and sport-specific expectations to all participants. 5. Implements procedures for injury prevention, medical care, and emergency response. 6. Completes and submits injury reports within 24 hours when required. 7. Directs and supervises student managers and assistants. 8. Enforces discipline in accordance with due process and communicates with parents as necessary. 9. Supports student-athletes with future educational or athletic planning when appropriate. Finance and Equipment 1. Participates in budgeting by identifying program needs and operating within approved allocations. 2. Maintains accountability for all equipment, including inventory, storage, issuance, and reconditioning. 3. Ensures proper identification, security, and authorized access to equipment and facilities. 4. Oversees locker room and facility cleanliness and ensures equipment is properly maintained. 5. Secures facilities upon departure and promotes respect for school property among student-athletes. Public Relations 1. Organizes and leads preseason meetings for parents and student-athletes. 2. Promotes the swim program within the school and community to encourage participation. 3. Ensures accuracy and professionalism in communications with local media. 4. Maintains positive relationships with parents, officials, volunteers, booster organizations, and the community. 5. Shares schedules, results, and program highlights with appropriate audiences. Job.JobTitle: Head Wrestling Coach - Massabesic Middle School
Job.JobDescription: Regional School Unit 57 Position Title: Head Wrestling Coach Reports To: High School Athletic Director, in conjunction with the Principal Qualifications Knowledge and background in the sport of wrestling. Meets RSU 57 eligibility requirements, including: First Aid Certification CPR Certification Concussion Management Course Heat Acclimatization Course RSU 57 Background Check Maine Department of Education Criminal History Record Check All requirements must be met within timelines specified by RSU 57. * Position Summary The Head Wrestling Coach is responsible for the planning, organization, supervision, and evaluation of the high school wrestling program. The Head Coach instructs student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategy, and physical conditioning necessary to achieve individual and team success while supporting the mission and athletic philosophy of RSU 57. Essential Duties and Responsibilities Organize and supervise all aspects of the high school wrestling program. Demonstrate thorough knowledge of local, state, and school athletic policies and procedures. Implement and enforce athletic department policies and team rules. Attend all required meetings as scheduled by the school, Athletic Director, and Maine Principals' Association (MPA). Emphasize the importance of academics, sportsmanship, citizenship, and character development as part of the athletic philosophy. Maintain high standards for athlete performance and conduct. Model appropriate behavior, professionalism, and sportsmanship at all times. Dress appropriately for practices, competitions, and meetings. Apply sound knowledge of the sport, including training and conditioning techniques. Seek opportunities for professional growth and incorporate new techniques and ideas when appropriate. Teach skills that are developmentally appropriate and safe for individual student-athletes. Supervise student-athletes at all times to ensure safety and accountability. Maintain, inventory, store, and care for athletic equipment and uniforms. Inspect equipment and facilities regularly to ensure safe conditions. Prepare for and supervise all scheduled practices, competitions, and events. Establish, communicate, and enforce appropriate team rules and expectations. Utilize appropriate emergency procedures and injury response protocols. Encourage leadership and positive behavior among student-athletes on and off the mat. Communicate promptly, professionally, and appropriately with parents and guardians. Participate in preseason informational meetings with parents/guardians and athletes. Interact effectively and appropriately with officials, opponents, and event personnel. Meet all deadlines for paperwork and related duties. Maintain required records and documentation for student-athletes. Perform other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or Principal. Language and Communication Skills Ability to read and interpret documents relevant to the position, including athletic policies, handbooks, and state guidelines. Ability to communicate clearly, concisely, and correctly in both oral and written form with parents, athletes, coaches, administrators, and officials. Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with administrators, coaching staff, athletes, parents, and the community. Mathematical Skills Basic understanding of budgeting, inventory management, and record-keeping practices. Physical Demands While performing the essential duties of this position, the employee is regularly required to stand, walk, talk, and hear. The position frequently requires physical demonstration of skills, including running, jumping, throwing, grappling techniques, and general body movement. The employee may be required to lift and carry items weighing more than 20 pounds. Occasional prolonged sitting and frequent travel by bus are required. Extended hours may be necessary to meet the demands of the position.
